document.docAuthor: Li, Weihai, Murányi, Dávid, Orci, Kirill Márk, Uchida, Shigekazu & Wang, Rongfeng
document.docTitle: Sinacroneuria obscura Li & Murányi & Orci & Uchida & Wang 2017, sp.n.
document.masterDocTitle: A new species of Sinacroneuria (Plecoptera: Perlidae) from Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, southcentral China based on male adult, larva and drumming signals, and validation of the Japanese species of the genus

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species of Sinacroneuria (Plecoptera: Perlidae) from Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, southcentral China based on male adult, larva and drumming signals, and validation of the Japanese species of the genus

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type
materials:
Holotype male ( HIST ), China : Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, Shangsi County, Shiwandashan National Forest Park, Pearl River above tourist route bridge,
375 m
, 21°59.913'N , 107°54.283'E , 2015
.
III.27
, leg. J. Kontschán , J.Y. Li , S. Li , W.H. Li , D. Murányi , G.Q. Wang. Paratypes : same locality and date: 2 male and 1 female penultimate larvae, 2 male exuviae ( HNHM : No. PLO86)
;
same locality but collected on 2015.
III.28
: 2 male and 1 female exuviae ( HIST ), 1 adult male, 1 female larva, 5 male and 1 female exuviae ( HNHM : No. PLO100); Shiwandashan National Forest Park, small forest brook,
365 m
, 21°50.574'N , 107°51.802'E , 2015
.
III.28
, leg. J. Kontschán , W.H. Li , D. Murányi , G.Q. Wang : 1 male exuviae ( HNHM : No PLO115).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–6.
Sinacroneuria obscura Li & Murányi
,
sp. n.
, holotype male.—1: head and pronotum, dorsal view; 2: terminalia, dorsal view; 3: terminalia, ventral view; 4: terminalia, lateral view; 5: paraproct, dorsal view; 6: hammer of sternum 9, ventral view—not to scale.

FIGURES 7–8.
Sinacroneuria obscura Li & Murányi
,
sp. n.
, holotype male.—7: aedeagus, dorsal view; 8: aedeagus, lateral view, with details of spines in lateral and caudal view—not to scale.

subSubSection.paragraph: Paraproct simple, bears small anal gill ( Figs. 9–10 , 14 ). Cercus long, lacks swimming hairs but elongated hairs of the medial row are forming distinct tufts on the inner surface of cercomeres; further portions of the row consist of long but not erect, pale setae mixed with long, fine hairs ( Figs. 13–14 ).

Drumming. Four drumming calls of only one male were recorded; therefore the present description of the male vibrational signal of the species should be regarded as preliminary revealing only the major rhythmic features of the vibratory male calls of this species. The duration and count values given in parentheses report the range measured in the signals of the studied specimen recorded at an ambient air temperature of 19.4o C. The drumming call of
S. obscura
consists of two beat groups ( Fig. 33 a). The first longer beat group (32-35 beats, duration between 732-838 ms) is followed by a second shorter beat group (5 beats invariably, duration 103-107 ms) after an interval shorter than the first beat group (inter beat group interval varied between 239-273 ms). In both beat groups, beat amplitude increases during the course of the group. In the first beat group beat intervals vary between 15-20 ms during the first low amplitude part (values above 30 ms occurs probably as a result of missing beats) and between 20-25 ms during the final high amplitude part ( Fig. 33 b). A short transitional part in the middle of the beat group can be observed where beat intervals show a tendentious increase. The second beat group beat intervals vary from 20-25 with an uncertain decreasing tendency ( Fig. 33 c).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 9–10.
Sinacroneuria obscura Li & Murányi
,
sp. n.
, female larva.—9: habitus, dorsal view; 10: habitus, ventral view—scale 1 mm.

FIGURES 11–16.
Sinacroneuria obscura Li & Murányi
,
sp. n.
, female larva and exuviae.—11: gill AT3, ventral view; 12: diagrammatic figure of thoracal gills arrangement, ventral view; 13: 10–11th cercal segments, ventral view; 14: basal half of cerci, ventral view; 15: left hind leg, dorsal view; 16: left hind leg, ventral view—scales 1 mm for Figs. 12, 15–16, 0.5 mm for Fig. 13, Figs 11, 14 not to scale.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution and ecology. The new species was collected from Pearl River, a submontane river and a small forest brook in the Shiwandashan National Forest Park, Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region of southcentral China . The Shiwandashan Mountains are part of a moderately high coastal range on the border of China and northeastern Vietnam , being relatively isolated from the main mountain chains of both Indochina and the southern Chinese mountain ranges. At the type locality, the Pearl River flows in dense, evergreen submontane forest at moderately low elevation, having fast flow with several cascades, and a rocky bed with very few organic deposits and coarse sand patches among the large rocks and stones ( Figs. 34–36 ). The stonefly fauna of the river is rather rich, besides the new species, twelve species (two Leuctridae , four Nemouridae , six Perlidae ) were found, among them further three are new and will be described in a future paper, including a new
Rhopalopsole Klapálek, 1912
species having been published recently (
Li et al . 2017
). The forest brook, a tributary of the Pinglong River, where we found a single exuviae, has reduced flow and is shallow but similar rocky bed as the Pearl River ( Fig. 37 ). Here the new species was found together with a another Perlidae , one Leuctridae and two Nemouridae species. According to high number of exuviae observed on emergent rocks, the new species appears relatively common in the Pearl River. Peak emergence apparently was completed by the time of our late March collecting, as we found only a single last instar larva despite several hours of searching.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 17–21.
Sinacroneuria obscura Li & Murányi
,
sp. n.
, female larva and exuviae.—17: proventriculus, dissected; 18: details of proventricular teeth; 19: setation of tergum 5 medial half, dorsal view; 20: setation of sternum 8 medial half, ventral view; 21: setation of the left occipital area of the head, dorsal view—scales 1 mm, Fig. 18 not to scale.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Etymology. The name
obscura
(from the Latin word obscurus, meaning obscure) refers to the reduced anterior ocellus. Used as an adjective, gender feminine.

Remarks. The new species is similar to
S. biocellata Stark & Sivec, 2008
from Vietnam , by sharing similar head pattern and two ocelli, and to
S. bicornuata Stark & Sivec, 2008
from Sichuan Province of southwestern China by absence of median sclerite in ventral surface of aedeagus. It may be easily separated by the latter by nearly divided sensilla basiconica patch of tergum 9 and parallel-sided basal trunk of Y-arms ( Figs. 2 , 7 ). The sensilla basiconica patch of tergum 9 in both
S. biocellata
and
S. bicornuata
are apparently fused ( Figs. 2, 5 in Stark & Sivec 2008 , Fig. 3 a in
Li et al . 2014
). Only the larva of
S. obscura
and
S. acuticornis
sp. n.
are known. The two species are being rather similar, but can be separated on the basis of different abdominal dorsal pattern ( Fig. 9 , compared to Fig. 14.4 in
Shimizu et al. 2005
).
